G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 19A..proposition: The amount of damages sought, exclusive of interest and costs, is within the jurisdictional limits of the Quincy District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2,.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the cause of action arose in Quincy, Norfolk County, Massachusetts, and the Defendant conducts business and maintains the Premises in Quincy.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: As a paying customer, Plaintiff was owed a duty of reasonable care by Defendant to maintain the Premises, including walkways, corridors, and hallways, in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn of any unreasonable dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence by Justice Kaplan criticizing the continued reliance on trespasser/licensee/invitee classifications. It does not set out or apply a specific rule about a landowner’s duty of reasonable care to paying customers or about maintaining premises and warning of dangers. While the main opinion in Mounsey generally moves toward a reasonable care standard for lawful visitors, this quoted passage does not itself articulate or apply the specific duty described in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a "licensee" rather than an "invitee," or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that "trespassers" stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85..proposition: As a paying customer, Plaintiff was owed a duty of reasonable care by Defendant to maintain the Premises, including walkways, corridors, and hallways, in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn of any unreasonable dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783–85 (2007).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant’s employees, agents, and/or servants, including the server who created the spill, had actual knowledge of the dangerous condition on the floor and, at a minimum, constructive knowledge due to the passage of time and the employees’ ongoing awareness of and encounters with the puddle.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly concerns whether a store can be liable without proof of actual or traditional constructive notice, by adopting the mode of operation doctrine. It does not state that a specific employee (such as a server who created a spill) had actual knowledge of the dangerous condition, nor does it rely on evidence that the grape or liquid had been on the floor long enough to establish constructive notice through the passage of time. Instead, the court holds that notice is satisfied by the foreseeability of such hazards inherent in the store’s self-service operation, thereby relaxing the traditional actual/constructive knowledge requirement that the proposition invokes.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Adopting this new approach to premises liability does not make the owner of a self-service or modern grocery store an insurer against all accidents, but instead removes the burden on the victim of a slip and fall to prove that the owner or the owner’s employees had actual or constructive notice of the dangerous condition or to prove the exact failure that caused the accident. … Under the mode of operation approach, a plaintiff’s proof of a particular mode-of-operation simply substitutes for the traditional elements of a prima facie case — the existence of a dangerous condition and notice of a dangerous condition.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Despite such knowledge, Defendant failed to exercise reasonable care to either promptly and adequately clean and dry the floor, or, at a minimum, to warn or protect patrons from the known dangerous condition.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The proposition assumes that the defendant had knowledge (actual or constructive) of the dangerous condition and then failed to exercise reasonable care to clean, dry, or warn. Oliveri focuses on whether there was sufficient evidence that the foreign substance had been present long enough to impute such knowledge and holds there was not, directing judgment for the defendant. While the opinion recites the general duty to keep premises reasonably safe or warn of dangers, it ultimately finds that duty not triggered on these facts because knowledge of the condition was not established.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know… The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s failure to maintain the Hallway in a reasonably safe condition and to take reasonable steps to protect and warn invitees of known hazards.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case deals with a slip-and-fall on ice in a mall parking lot and addresses the general duty of property owners to use reasonable care to maintain premises safely, abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction. It does not involve a hallway, nor does it specifically analyze foreseeability of a particular plaintiff’s injuries in the way the proposition states; rather, it articulates a general reasonable-care standard for snow and ice. Thus, while it is broadly consistent with a duty to maintain safe conditions for invitees, it does not specifically support the detailed foreseeability proposition as phrased.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980)… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842–44 (1987).
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, by and through its employees, agents, and/or servants acting within the course and scope of their employment, owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of or remedy any dangerous conditions they created, knew of, or should have known of in the exercise of reasonable care.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion addresses only whether the defendant had a duty to warn customers of the obvious risk of negligent operation of other vehicles at a self-service gas station. It explicitly concludes there is no duty to warn of that inherent and obvious danger, which cuts against, rather than supports, a broad proposition that defendant owed a duty to warn of or remedy dangerous conditions it knew or should have known about. The excerpt does not set out a general premises-liability duty as framed in the proposition; it narrows and rejects a claimed warning duty in this context.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212\.proposition: Plaintiff did not assume the risk of Defendant’s negligence and did not knowingly or voluntarily encounter a known danger; instead, she reasonably relied on Defendant to maintain the Hallway in a safe condition or to warn of any hazards.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212\.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence from Poirier v. Plymouth concerns the sufficiency of evidence of a hidden or concealed defect and the court’s treatment of the ‘hidden defect’ rule in premises liability. It does not discuss assumption of risk, voluntary encounter with a known danger, or a plaintiff’s reliance on a defendant to maintain safe conditions or warn of hazards. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about assumption of risk and reasonable reliance stated by the user.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 212\.relevant_excerpt: "This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict. The Appeals Court agreed, reversed the judgment and vacated the verdict. On the plaintiff’s appeal therefrom this court is ordering that the verdict and judgment for the plaintiff be reinstated, holding that the evidence was sufficient to support the verdict."

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961).
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the storekeeper’s duty to customers to keep premises reasonably safe, and explains that when a dangerous condition arises without the defendant’s fault, the defendant must have a reasonable opportunity to learn of it and either remedy it or warn customers. The court’s discussion of constructive notice, opportunity for discovery, and the need to discover and remove or warn about hazards supports the stated duties of reasonable maintenance, inspection, remediation, and warning to invitees, even though the plaintiff ultimately failed to prove breach on the facts.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action.… [I]t was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.raw_text: Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874, 879 (1978) (knowledge of employees imputed to employer).
Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.proposition: The actual knowledge of Defendant’s employee who caused the spill, coupled with the statements of other staff that they had been “dodging that puddle” for a while, establishes that Defendant had actual notice of the dangerous condition and had a reasonable opportunity to remedy or warn of it.
Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns negligent design of a refuse truck and issues of warnings, assumption of risk, and product liability standards. It does not address premises liability, notice of dangerous conditions, or imputation of employees’ knowledge to an employer. There is no discussion of an employee-caused spill, staff comments about a puddle, or actual/constructive notice, so it cannot support the stated proposition about imputing employees’ knowledge to establish a defendant’s actual notice and opportunity to remedy a hazard.
Uloth v. City Tank Corp., 376 Mass. 874,.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that there was no error in the judge’s denial of City Tank and Old Dominion’s motions for directed verdicts, for judgments notwithstanding the verdicts, or for a new trial.

Foley v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 2.raw_text: Foley v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 232, 233–35 (1936).
Foley v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 2.proposition: Alternatively, the condition of the floor and the length of time the water and ice remained on the floor, together with the employees’ observations and comments, were such that, in the exercise of reasonable care, Defendant should have discovered and remedied the condition, thereby establishing at least constructive notice.
Foley v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 2.case_name: Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co.
Foley v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses constructive notice based on the condition of the foreign substance and the time it must have been present, combined with the proximity and visibility to employees. The court holds that from the character, consistency, dryness, and appearance of the vomit, the jury could infer it had been there long enough that it should have been discovered and removed by employees exercising reasonable care, and emphasizes that employees’ vantage points made the condition observable for a sufficient time to charge the defendant with notice.
Foley v. F.W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: “There was no direct evidence as to when the substance came into existence on the stairs. Nevertheless, from its character, its consistency, dryness, hardness and general appearance the jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that it had been on the stairway long enough to have been known of and removed before the accident… a substance of the character described could not have been where it was without being exposed to the view of the waitresses at the ten counters near the foot of the stairs for a length of time sufficient for notice… and for the removal of the condition…”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s breach of its duty of care was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries. But for Defendant’s negligent failure to clean the spill, to warn of the wet condition, or to restrict access to the Hallway, Plaintiff would not have slipped and injured her knee.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence in paroling a violent prisoner was the proximate cause of a police officer’s later shooting, and the court holds as a matter of law that proximate cause is lacking due to intervening and superseding causes. The opinion does not involve a premises-liability slip-and-fall, a duty to clean spills, or to warn/restrict access to a hallway; instead, it rejects, rather than affirms, a causal link between the defendant’s conduct and the plaintiff’s injuries. Citing this case to show that a defendant’s negligent failure to clean a spill was the direct and proximate cause of a fall misstates its holding and context.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “The Commonwealth argues that, even based on a broad reading of the complaint and all of its allegations, the parole board’s decision in 1987 cannot, as a matter of law, be the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ harm that occurred in 1995. We agree… Because the duty to prevent harm, and the risk created by MacNeil’s release, were transferred to a law enforcement agency that could lawfully be relied on to perform safely the responsibilities it had assumed, the element of proximate cause… was extinguished… The Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the claims for negligence should have been allowed.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F..proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred and will continue to incur reasonable and necessary medical expenses, currently estimated at approximately $2,200, for the evaluation, care, and treatment of her injuries, and will likely incur additional medical expenses in the future.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered, and continues to suffer, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, inconvenience, and emotional distress, all as a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a tenant’s recovery of emotional distress and other damages under G.L. c. 93A and for intentional infliction of emotional distress, not a negligence claim. It does not address pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, or emotional distress as elements of damages in a negligence action, nor does it use proximate-cause language in the way the proposition frames it. Thus, it is not proper authority for the specific negligence-damages proposition cited.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.relevant_excerpt: "On the emotional distress counterclaim, the judge determined that Gonzalez had proved that Haddad's intentional and outrageous conduct had caused her to suffer severe emotional distress, and that such proof constituted a basis for recovery under c. 93A. The judge then placed a value of $18,000 on Gonzalez's emotional distress."

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–21 (2002).
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: Defendant is vicariously liable under the doctrine of respondeat superior for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees, agents, and/or servants, including the server who caused and failed to remedy or adequately warn of the spill, as such acts and omissions occurred within the course and scope of their employment.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The case supports the general rule of respondeat superior—that an employer is vicariously liable for torts of its employees committed within the scope of employment—but it does so in the context of a medical practice group and a physician, not a premises-liability context involving a server and a spill. The opinion does not address duties regarding spills, warnings, or premises safety, nor does it discuss liability of a restaurant or similar establishment for acts of a server. Thus it is authority for the basic respondeat superior principle, but not for the specific proposition about a server causing or failing to remedy a spill.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B;.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including without limitation G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable Massachusetts law.
